page.title: 05Ecology in Dean
page.content: The pattern of the area is one of large fields and narrow curving lanes, emphasised in places by the hedges. Trees and hedges are especiallt prominent around Dean Church, Dean House and the Grange in Upper Dean and alongside the brook in Lower Dean. There are several important areas of woodland, the 2 largest being at the east side of Upper Dean and Spanoak Wood about 0.5 mile to the east of Upper Dean. All the woodland areas are mainly deciduous. Many of the elm trees have now been felled but work is progressing in several areas with the planting of new trees. Dean was one of the last areas in the county to be affected by Dutch Elm disease.
